data.title: The 12 'most notable' people from North Wales including James Bond star and LFC legend
data.meta_description: A new study has revealed the 'most notable' people from across the region and includes Hollywood actors and sports stars
data.text:
There’s no denying Wales has produced some absolute icons, including actors, singers, comedians and sports stars, with many hailing from the North.

A new study published by Nature has identified the "most notable" people from cities, towns and villages around the world, including right here in North Wales. Each person included in the study was determined using information from Wikipedia and Wikidata.

Each celebrity’s notability is based on a selection of things, including the number of Wikipedia editions with each individual, the length of their biographies, the number of views for each between 2015 and 2018, and the amount of information retrieved on each person. Geographer and map designer Topi Tjukanov has turned the data into an interactive map pinpointing exactly where each famous face is from.

READ MORE:

Throwback photos show The Beatles visiting Bangor 55 years ago

Strictly Come Dancing's 19 previous winners and their most memorable moments ahead of 2022 series

Below is a selection of the "most notable people'' from North Wales. Although you’ll know many of the celebrities that come from our area, you may not know the exact place they’re from. Some of the below may be a complete surprise, with you never knowing they were born nearby.

Of course, there are many more famous faces from North Wales, but what the survey shows is that a variety of talented people have come from our neck of the woods.

Colwyn Bay - Timothy Dalton

Actor Timothy Dalton (born 1946) is best known for playing James Bond in the much-loved film franchise. Dalton played the secret agent in two films - The Living Daylights and Licence to Kill.

Bangor - Duffy

Singer Duffy (born 1984) gained worldwide fame after the release of her debut album, Rockferry, in 2008. Her hits include Mercy, Warwick Avenue and Rain On Your Parade.

Caernarfon - Edward II of England

Edward II (1284-1327), also known as Edward of Caernarfon, was the fourth son of Edward I. He was born in Caernarfon Castle on April 25, 1284, less than a year after his father had conquered the region. He was King of England and Lord of Ireland from 1307 until he was removed in 1327.

St Asaph - Ian Rush

Former professional footballer Ian Rush (born 1961) played as a forward for Liverpool from 1980-1987 and from 1988-1996. He is LFC’s all-time leading goal scorer and also made 73 appearances for the Wales national football team where he remained the record goalscorer until 2018.

Denbigh - Henry Morton Stanley

Henry Morton Stanley (1841-1904) was an explorer, journalist, soldier, colonial administrator, author and politician. He’s most famous for his exploration of Central Africa, including finding the sources of the Nile and Congo rivers, and his mission to find explorer David Livingstone.

Prestatyn - John Prescott

Former Labour MP John Prescott (born 1938) served as the UK’s Deputy Prime Minister from 1997 to 2007 and was the First Secretary of State from 2001 to 2007. Prescott was Member of Parliament for Kingston upon Hull East from 1970 to 2010.

Holyhead - Dawn French

Comedian, actress and writer Dawn French (born 1957) is best known for writing and starring in the BBC comedy sketch show French and Saunders alongside Jennifer Saunders. French also played the iconic role of Geraldine Granger in the BBC sitcom The Vicar of Dibley.

Marianglas - Hugh Griffith

Hugh Griffith (1912-1980) was a film, stage, and television actor. His most iconic role was in the film Ben-Hur where he won an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor. Griffith’s other work includes Oliver!, How To Steal A Million and Tom Jones.

Mancot - Gary Speed

Gary Speed (1969-2011) was a professional footballer and manager. He played for Leeds United, Everton, Newcastle United, Bolton Wanderers and Sheffield United, and captained the Welsh national team until his retirement in 2004. Speed later returned to manage Wales in 2010 where he remained until his death in 2011.

Tremadog - T E Lawrence

Thomas Edward Lawrence (1888-1935) was an archaeologist, army officer, diplomat, and writer. He’s known for his achievements during the First World War, including his role in the Arab Revolt and the Sinai and Palestine Campaign against the Ottoman Empire, and acquired the nickname Lawrence Of Arabia.

Ruabon - Mark Hughes

Mark Hughes (born 1963) is a former player and currently the manager of Bradford City. Hughes played for Manchester United, Barcelona, Bayern Munich, Chelsea, Southampton, Everton and Blackburn Rovers. He made 72 appearances for the Welsh national football team and was appointed manager in 1999 where he remained until 2004.

Amlwch - Andy Whitfield

Actor Andy Whitfield (1971-2011) was best known for playing Spartacus in the Starz television series Spartacus: Blood and Sand. He passed away in 2011 after being diagnosed with cancer in 2010.

Who's your favourite celebrity from North Wales? Let us know in the comments section below.
